bill_title: provide for the practice and regulation of registered midwives.

bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to provide for the practice and regulation of registered midwives. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Health; (2) "Registered midwife," any person who has been registered to practice midwifery pursuant to this Act. Section 2. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, to establish practice guidelines for registered midwives that are substantially similar to the "Practice Guidelines for Out of Hospital Birth by Certified Nurse Midwives in South Dakota" established by the Board of Nursing and the Board of Medical and Osteopathic Examiners for certified nurse midwives. However, the practice guidelines for registered midwives may not include prescriptive authority but shall include a list of medications that a registered midwife may administer after completing a pharmacology course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department that covers any medication on the list and the use of the medication in the out-of-hospital setting. The practice guidelines shall also include the provision of care and services that is limited to the following: (1) Monitoring the physical, psychological, and social well-being of the mother throughout the childbearing cycle; (2) Providing the mother with individualized education, counseling and prenatal care, continuous hands-on assistance during labor and delivery, and postpartum support; (3) Monitoring and supporting the baby during the pregnancy, labor, delivery and postpartum period; and (4) Identifying and referring women and newborns who require medical attention. Section 3. No person may practice as a registered midwife unless that person is registered with the department pursuant to this Act. No person may use the title, registered midwife, to describe or imply that he or she is a registered midwife, or represent himself or herself as a registered midwife unless the person is granted registration pursuant to this Act. A violation of this section is a Class 2 misdemeanor. The following persons are exempt from the registration requirements of this Act: (1) Any certified nurse midwife, registered nurse, or licensed nurse practitioner authorized to practice in South Dakota; (2) Any student midwife engaged in an internship, preceptorship, or other clinical training program, who is under the direction and supervision of a preceptor recognized by the North American Registry of Midwives; and (3) Any person exempt pursuant to § 36-2-20. Section 4. Any person seeking registration under this Act shall complete the application prescribed by the department and submit the application along with the registration fee to the department. The registration shall be renewed annually by payment of the renewal fee and proof that the midwife has maintained his or her certification with the North American Registry of Midwives. A registration not renewed by December thirty-first of each year lapses. Any fee collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the general fund. Section 5. The department shall register any midwife who has submitted a completed application form, paid the registration fee, and met the following requirements: (1) Is at least twenty-one years of age at the time of application; (2) Has earned a high school diploma or the equivalent; (3) Has earned and maintains the Certified Professional Midwife credential issued by the North American Registry of Midwives accredited by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies; (4) Has earned and maintains certification in neonatal resuscitation obtained through completion of American Heart Association approved cardiopulmonary resuscitation courses or American Academy of Pediatrics approved neonatal resuscitation courses; and (5) Has successfully completed a course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department in suturing, intravenous fluid resuscitation, and pharmacology that covers any medication on the list established by the department; and (6) Has provided the department with fingerprints and other information necessary for a criminal background investigation and has been shown not to have committed any felonies. Section 6. The department may adopt rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, in the following areas: (1) Content of applications; (2) Fees for initial registration and renewal not to exceed one hundred dollars; and (3) Renewal of registration. Section 7. The registration of a midwife may be revoked or suspended upon violation of the practice guidelines established by the department. Any proceeding concerning the revocation or suspension of a registration shall conform to the contested case procedure set forth in chapter 1-26. Section 8. A registered midwife shall report to the department any termination, revocation, or suspension of the registered midwife's certification within five days of being notified of such action. Section 9. A registered midwife shall file birth certificates with the department in accordance with § 34-25-8. Filing a birth certificate known by the registered midwife to be fraudulent is a Class 2 misdemeanor. Section 10. In addition to the plan of care agreement detailed in the practice guidelines a registered midwife shall, at an initial consultation with a client, provide a copy of an informed consent document to be signed by the registered midwife and the client, which document shall disclose to the client, in writing, all of the following: (1) The registered midwife's experience, qualifications, and training; (2) Whether or not the registered midwife has malpractice liability insurance; (3) A plan for consultation, referral, and transport for medical emergencies specific to each client, including identification of the closest hospital with labor and delivery services, the closest hospital with an emergency department, and a physician who will be called for consultation. Section 11. Nothing in this Act permits a registered midwife to provide services in a hospital licensed pursuant to chapter 34-12 unless the hospital has specifically granted such privileges. Section 12. No registered midwife may use forceps or vacuum extraction or perform cesarean sections or abortions. Section 13. No licensed health care provider or hospital or agent thereof is liable for an injury resulting from an act or omission by a registered midwife. Section 14. That chapter 36-9 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse. Section 15. That chapter 36-9A be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a nurse practitioner or certified nurse midwife. Section 16. That chapter 36-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a physician or surgeon.

bill_versions.bill_version: House Health and Human Services Engrossed
bill_versions.bill_text: FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to provide for the practice and regulation of registered midwives. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Health; (2) "Registered midwife," any person who has been registered to practice midwifery pursuant to this Act. Section 2. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, to establish practice guidelines for registered midwives that are substantially similar to the "Practice Guidelines for Out of Hospital Birth by Certified Nurse Midwives in South Dakota" established by the Board of Nursing and the Board of Medical and Osteopathic Examiners for certified nurse midwives. However, the practice guidelines for registered midwives may not include prescriptive authority but shall include a list of medications that a registered midwife may administer after completing a pharmacology course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department that covers any medication on the list and the use of the medication in the out-of-hospital setting. The practice guidelines shall also include the provision of care and services that is limited to the following: (1) Monitoring the physical, psychological, and social well-being of the mother throughout the childbearing cycle; (2) Providing the mother with individualized education, counseling and prenatal care, continuous hands-on assistance during labor and delivery, and postpartum support; (3) Monitoring and supporting the baby during the pregnancy, labor, delivery and postpartum period; and (4) Identifying and referring women and newborns who require medical attention. Section 3. No person may practice as a registered midwife unless that person is registered with the department pursuant to this Act. No person may use the title, registered midwife, to describe or imply that he or she is a registered midwife, or represent himself or herself as a registered midwife unless the person is granted registration pursuant to this Act. A violation of this section is a Class 2 misdemeanor. The following persons are exempt from the registration requirements of this Act: (1) Any certified nurse midwife, registered nurse, or licensed nurse practitioner authorized to practice in South Dakota; (2) Any student midwife engaged in an internship, preceptorship, or other clinical training program, who is under the direction and supervision of a preceptor recognized by the North American Registry of Midwives; and (3) Any person exempt pursuant to § 36-2-20. Section 4. Any person seeking registration under this Act shall complete the application prescribed by the department and submit the application along with the registration fee to the department. The registration shall be renewed annually by payment of the renewal fee and proof that the midwife has maintained his or her certification with the North American Registry of Midwives. A registration not renewed by December thirty-first of each year lapses. Any fee collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the general fund. Section 5. The department shall register any midwife who has submitted a completed application form, paid the registration fee, and met the following requirements: (1) Is at least twenty-one years of age at the time of application; (2) Has earned a high school diploma or the equivalent; (3) Has earned and maintains the Certified Professional Midwife credential issued by the North American Registry of Midwives accredited by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies; (4) Has earned and maintains certification in neonatal resuscitation obtained through completion of American Heart Association approved cardiopulmonary resuscitation courses or American Academy of Pediatrics approved neonatal resuscitation courses; and (5) Has successfully completed a course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department in suturing, intravenous fluid resuscitation, and pharmacology that covers any medication on the list established by the department; and (6) Has provided the department with fingerprints and other information necessary for a criminal background investigation and has been shown not to have committed any felonies. Section 6. The department may adopt rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, in the following areas: (1) Content of applications; (2) Fees for initial registration and renewal not to exceed one hundred dollars; and (3) Renewal of registration. Section 7. The registration of a midwife may be revoked or suspended upon violation of the practice guidelines established by the department. Any proceeding concerning the revocation or suspension of a registration shall conform to the contested case procedure set forth in chapter 1-26. Section 8. A registered midwife shall report to the department any termination, revocation, or suspension of the registered midwife's certification within five days of being notified of such action. Section 9. A registered midwife shall file birth certificates with the department in accordance with § 34-25-8. Filing a birth certificate known by the registered midwife to be fraudulent is a Class 2 misdemeanor. Section 10. In addition to the plan of care agreement detailed in the practice guidelines a registered midwife shall, at an initial consultation with a client, provide a copy of an informed consent document to be signed by the registered midwife and the client, which document shall disclose to the client, in writing, all of the following: (1) The registered midwife's experience, qualifications, and training; (2) Whether or not the registered midwife has malpractice liability insurance; (3) A plan for consultation, referral, and transport for medical emergencies specific to each client, including identification of the closest hospital with labor and delivery services, the closest hospital with an emergency department, and a physician who will be called for consultation. The registered midwife shall provide the client's health records to the hospital identified in the transport plan at least one month prior to the expected delivery date. However, no client health records may be transmitted unless the client has provided specific consent permitting the midwife to share the client's health records with the hospital in compliance with this section and with relevant federal and state patient privacy laws. A copy of the signed consent shall be transmitted to the hospital with the health records. If consent is not granted by the client, the midwife shall notify the hospital that the hospital is included in a home birth transport plan and identify the estimated due date. In any event, if there is no transport, the registered midwife shall notify the hospital within one week after delivery. Section 11. Nothing in this Act permits a registered midwife to provide services in a hospital licensed pursuant to chapter 34-12 unless the hospital has specifically granted such privileges. Section 12. No registered midwife may use forceps or vacuum extraction or perform cesarean sections or abortions. Section 13. No licensed health care provider or hospital or agent thereof is liable for any injury which directly or indirectly arises out of, or is the result of, an act or omission by a registered midwife. Section 14. That chapter 36-9 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse. Section 15. That chapter 36-9A be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a nurse practitioner or certified nurse midwife. Section 16. That chapter 36-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a physician or surgeon.

FOR AN ACT ENTITLED, An Act to provide for the practice and regulation of registered midwives. BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF SOUTH DAKOTA: Section 1. Terms used in this Act mean: (1) "Department," the Department of Health; (2) "Registered midwife," any person who has been registered to practice midwifery pursuant to this Act. Section 2. The department shall promulgate rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, to establish practice guidelines for registered midwives that are substantially similar to the "Practice Guidelines for Out of Hospital Birth by Certified Nurse Midwives in South Dakota" established by the Board of Nursing and the Board of Medical and Osteopathic Examiners for certified nurse midwives. However, the practice guidelines for registered midwives may not include prescriptive authority but shall include a list of medications that a registered midwife may administer after completing a pharmacology course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department that covers any medication on the list and the use of the medication in the out-of-hospital setting. The practice guidelines shall also include the provision of care and services that is limited to the following: (1) Monitoring the physical, psychological, and social well-being of the mother throughout the childbearing cycle; (2) Providing the mother with individualized education, counseling and prenatal care, continuous hands-on assistance during labor and delivery, and postpartum support; (3) Monitoring and supporting the baby during the pregnancy, labor, delivery and postpartum period; and (4) Identifying and referring women and newborns who require medical attention. Section 3. No person may practice as a registered midwife unless that person is registered with the department pursuant to this Act. No person may use the title, registered midwife, to describe or imply that he or she is a registered midwife, or represent himself or herself as a registered midwife unless the person is granted registration pursuant to this Act. A violation of this section is a Class 2 misdemeanor. The following persons are exempt from the registration requirements of this Act: (1) Any certified nurse midwife, registered nurse, or licensed nurse practitioner authorized to practice in South Dakota; (2) Any student midwife engaged in an internship, preceptorship, or other clinical training program, who is under the direction and supervision of a preceptor recognized by the North American Registry of Midwives; and (3) Any person exempt pursuant to § 36-2-20. Section 4. Any person seeking registration under this Act shall complete the application prescribed by the department and submit the application along with the registration fee to the department. The registration shall be renewed annually by payment of the renewal fee and proof that the midwife has maintained his or her certification with the North American Registry of Midwives. A registration not renewed by December thirty-first of each year lapses. Any fee collected pursuant to this section shall be deposited in the general fund. Section 5. The department shall register any midwife who has submitted a completed application form, paid the registration fee, and met the following requirements: (1) Is at least twenty-one years of age at the time of application; (2) Has earned a high school diploma or the equivalent; (3) Has earned and maintains the Certified Professional Midwife credential issued by the North American Registry of Midwives accredited by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies; (4) Has earned and maintains certification in neonatal resuscitation obtained through completion of American Heart Association approved cardiopulmonary resuscitation courses or American Academy of Pediatrics approved neonatal resuscitation courses; and (5) Has successfully completed a course accredited by the Midwifery Education Accreditation Council or approved by the department in suturing, intravenous fluid resuscitation, and pharmacology that covers any medication on the list established by the department; and (6) Has submitted to a state and federal criminal background investigation by means of fingerprint checks by the Division of Criminal Investigation and the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Upon application, the department shall submit completed fingerprint cards to the Division of Criminal Investigation. Upon completion of the criminal background check, the Division of Criminal Investigation shall forward to the department all information obtained as a result of the criminal background check. This information shall be obtained prior to registration of the applicant. Failure to submit or cooperate with the criminal background investigation or a record of a felony conviction is grounds for denial of an application. The applicant shall pay for any fees charged for the cost of fingerprinting or the criminal background investigation. Section 6. The department may adopt rules, pursuant to chapter 1-26, in the following areas: (1) Content of applications; (2) Fees for initial registration and renewal not to exceed one hundred dollars; and (3) Renewal of registration. Section 7. If the department deems it appropriate, the department may, in compliance with chapter 1-26: (1) Issue a reprimand to the registered midwife; (2) Place the registered midwife on probation and supervision; (3) Suspend the registered midwife's registration until the registered midwife completes a course of therapy, treatment, training, or any combination thereof; (4) Suspend the registered midwife's registration for a fixed period; or (5) Revoke the registered midwife's certificate. Section 8. A registered midwife shall report to the department any termination, revocation, or suspension of the registered midwife's certification within five days of being notified of such action. Section 9. A registered midwife shall file birth certificates with the department in accordance with § 34-25-8. Filing a birth certificate known by the registered midwife to be fraudulent is a Class 2 misdemeanor. Section 10. In addition to the plan of care agreement detailed in the practice guidelines a registered midwife shall, at an initial consultation with a client, provide a copy of an informed consent document to be signed by the registered midwife and the client, which document shall disclose to the client, in writing, all of the following: (1) The registered midwife's experience, qualifications, and training; (2) Whether or not the registered midwife has malpractice liability insurance; (3) A plan for consultation, referral, and transport for medical emergencies specific to each client, including identification of the closest hospital with labor and delivery services, the closest hospital with an emergency department, and a physician who will be called for consultation. The registered midwife shall provide the client's health records to the hospital identified in the transport plan at least one month prior to the expected delivery date. However, no client health records may be transmitted unless the client has provided specific consent permitting the midwife to share the client's health records with the hospital in compliance with this section and with relevant federal and state patient privacy laws. A copy of the signed consent shall be transmitted to the hospital with the health records. If consent is not granted by the client, the midwife shall notify the hospital that the hospital is included in a home birth transport plan and identify the estimated due date. In any event, if there is no transport, the registered midwife shall notify the hospital within one week after delivery. Section 11. Nothing in this Act permits a registered midwife to provide services in a hospital licensed pursuant to chapter 34-12 unless the hospital has specifically granted such privileges. Section 12. No registered midwife may use forceps or vacuum extraction or perform cesarean sections or abortions. Section 13. No licensed health care provider or hospital or agent thereof is liable for any injury which directly or indirectly arises out of, or is the result of, an act or omission by a registered midwife. Section 14. That chapter 36-9 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a registered nurse or licensed practical nurse. Section 15. That chapter 36-9A be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a nurse practitioner or certified nurse midwife. Section 16. That chapter 36-4 be amended by adding thereto a NEW SECTION to read as follows: Nothing in this chapter may be construed as prohibiting the care and services described in section 2 of this Act, provided in the performance of his or her duties, by a registered midwife registered pursuant to this Act, so long as the registered midwife does not claim to be a physician or surgeon.
